newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Security Council retains sanctions against Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Security Council retains sanctions against Iraq.

text.p: The Security Council made no change on Tuesday in stiff economic sanctions, including a ban on oil sales, imposed on Iraq since its August 1990 invasion of Kuwait.

The council decision was made during a regular review of the curbs conducted every 60 days. It was not directly related to Iraq's weekend attack on a Kurdish-held area in the north of the country which drew a response early Tuesday from the United States in the form of missile strikes against targets in southern Iraq.

But even without Iraq's lunge into the Kurdish area, where the United States and its Western allies have maintained a no-fly zone since the end of the Gulf War, the council would still have retained the sanctions intact.
A prime condition for any easing is a clean bill of health from the U.N. Special Commission (UNSCOM) in charge of scrapping Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.

UNSCOM chief Rolf Ekeus, who briefed the council on a recent trip to Iraq, told reporters he was still far from satisfied that Baghdad had made a full disclosure, citing shortcomings in the areas of missiles, chemical and biological programmes and related documents.
"Iraq has not accounted for the missile capability fully," he said, adding that between six and 16 were unaccounted for.
